sequences: Australia has a strong tradition of an honest days pay for an honest days work. We have a strong union presence which leads to high wages backed by a strong resource economy. We also have a very multicultural society with many immigrants choosing to settle in Australia this leads to diverse shopping areas where goods originally made all over the world are made right here on our shores. The main reason Australia is the best country in the world is our heavily ingrained concept of a "fair go" meaning you give anybody a chance to prove themselves no matter who they are. This is not even mentioning our spectacular landscapes and beaches. All in all Australia is the best country in the world.

Australia values hard work and fair pay. We have strong unions that help ensure high wages, supported by a rich resource economy. Our society is diverse, with many immigrants who create vibrant shopping areas. These areas offer goods from around the world, made right here in Australia. One of the best things about Australia is the idea of a "fair go." This means everyone deserves a chance to prove themselves, no matter who they are. Plus, we have amazing landscapes and beautiful beaches. Overall, Australia is a wonderful country.

If something is important enough to cover in a website, then it should be easily found within the core content of the site and not shoved into an FAQ section. I think people only ever turn to FAQ pages if rhey can't find what they want within the main site. When clients demand an FAQ page, I will challenge this and ask them to rethink what should be in the core copy and what is irrelevant. If the information is already within the main content, and they still want an FAQ section, they are just adding unnecessary repetition into the content. Websites should Never include an FAQ section and I cant find an argument to support their use other than improving SEO. Change my view.

I think that foreign direct investment in general is sound practice and benefits both parties, but have recently had many people say its a bad thing but without being able to explain any sound reasoning. Current example which has brought the issue up is the talks of Indonesian purchase of land for cattle farming in Australia: Australia benefits from increased taxes, extra jobs, development of Australian agricultural industry, repairs damage from hastily putting a temporary ban on live cattle transport. Indonesia gets a guaranteed source of cattle, gets a return on their investment, learns from any farming techniques they learn from Australian farmers they hire. Change my view

I believe that foreign direct investment is generally a good practice that helps both sides. Recently, I have heard many people say it is bad, but they can't explain why. A current example is Indonesia wanting to buy land in Australia for cattle farming. Australia would gain more tax money, create more jobs, and improve its agricultural industry. It would also help fix problems caused by a quick ban on live cattle transport. Indonesia would get a steady supply of cattle, earn a profit from its investment, and learn farming techniques from the Australian farmers they hire. Please help me see a different perspective.

I think foreign direct investment is usually beneficial for both parties. Recently, I've heard many people claim it’s harmful, but they don't explain their reasons. For example, Indonesia wants to buy land in Australia for cattle farming. Australia would benefit by getting more tax revenue, creating jobs, and boosting its agricultural sector. This investment could also help solve issues caused by a recent ban on live cattle transport. On the other hand, Indonesia would get a reliable supply of cattle, make money from its investment, and learn farming techniques from Australian farmers they employ. I would like to understand a different viewpoint.

Currently, there are a variety of benefits offered to US military veterans. So many that there is an entire department, the Department of Veterans Affairs, responsible for overseeing them. I don't see any reason to hold your country in higher regard simply because you were born within the arbitrary lines that define it. I think patriotism leads to ethnocentrism and a very skewed perception of the entire world where your country is perfect and many others are evil. I'm not saying that supporting your country is wrong in a situation you feel they're doing good. I'm not saying you can't love your country. I just think blind faith in your leaders allows atrocities to happen while excusing you or your leaders from ever admitting them.

It’s okay to support your country when it’s doing good things. It’s also fine to love your country. But I think that blindly trusting your leaders can lead to terrible actions, and it makes it hard for people to recognize or admit those actions.

Testosterone aromatization in the early stages of infancy is one of the least understood processes of human development. The levels of free testosterone in a mother's womb have been shown to impact cognitive development , enhancing "autistic" traits in people exposed to high levels. Female fetuses have shown high levels of alpha feto-protien, which binds to the estrogen associated with "masculating" the brains of male infants. Kalat JW (2009). "Reproductive behaviors." Biological psychology. Belmont, Calif: Wadsworth, Cengage Learning. p. 321. ISBN 0-495-60300-7 I believe the levels of AFP or aromatase are the best targets for early autism detection, as these proteins are at the front lines when it comes to masculinity and the associated cognitive development.

Testosterone aromatization during early infancy is not well understood. Research shows that high levels of free testosterone in the womb can affect brain development and increase traits related to autism in those exposed to it. Female fetuses have high levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), which binds to estrogen and influences brain development in male infants. I think that measuring levels of AFP or aromatase could be helpful for detecting autism early, as these proteins play a crucial role in masculinity and brain development.

We don't know much about how testosterone changes in baby boys during early infancy. Studies suggest that high levels of free testosterone in the womb can affect brain development and may lead to more traits related to autism. Female fetuses have a lot of a protein called alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). This protein binds to estrogen and helps shape brain development in baby boys. I believe that checking the levels of AFP or aromatase could help us detect autism early. These proteins are important for male traits and brain growth.

Female fetuses produce a lot of a protein called alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). This protein binds to estrogen and helps with brain development in baby boys. I think measuring the levels of AFP or aromatase could help us find signs of autism early. These proteins are important for developing male traits and supporting brain growth.

For the most part, people use the word "manipulation" to paint with too wide a brush. Disciplining my child is an attempt to manipulate them into good behavior. Emotional manipulation is a way to inspire good behavior in others, and can be a completely valid way to create good social morality. Without pressure from others, many people may never put forth personal effort. Obviously there can be negative manipulation, when a narcissistic person attempts to control the behaviors of others without any regard for the other person. This is what people usually mean when they speak of "manipulation" but they have deluded themselves that any effort to put a check on the behavior of others is also bad. You can and should manipulate people for their own good, especially those closest to you.
But it's okay to guide people for their own good, especially those who are close to you.
It's fine to help people for their own good, especially if they are close to you.

It's good to help people, especially those who are close to you.

Helping people is important, especially those you care about.

I believe that nature will always balance itself in the end. I also believe that there is no "correct" ecosystem for an area and it is pointless to try and prevent one from changing. For example: if a species of animal were to go extinct, it may have a huge impact on the ecosystem it is home to. However, once this animal is gone, the environment will change and adapt and will still be an ecosystem in the end. The same can be said for global warming. Even if the temperatures change and the water levels of earth rise, it will create new environments and opportunities for other species of animal to take over. I can't think of a scenario where nature won't eventually take itself back. Change my view please.

Restaurants aren't required to list ingredients because it would be very involved to list every single ingredient that is in each serving and dishes are not made from a factory; they are made subjectively and may vary from dish to dish. They aren't required to list percentages as long as they are listed in order of abundance. Completely different types of memory. Flash memory is incredibly simple, low power, and doesn't lose it's state. The problem is it is incredibly slow (at least as far as circuits go). We also are pretty good at stacking flash memory, as heat really isn't a concern due to the low amount of operations. RAM really isn't stacked. It's built for speed, so it isn't just a gigantic NAND or NOR array. Because it operates fast, it draws a lot of current and gets pretty hot. So you can only put so much in an area and still adequately cool it.

On the other hand, RAM is designed for speed. It is not just a large array of NAND or NOR cells. Because it works quickly, RAM uses a lot of power and can get hot. This means we can’t fit too much RAM in a small space without overheating.

There's loads of different ways to pop or equalise your ears to the water pressure. The normal one we use would be pinch your nose and I'm guessing that's what you're expecting them to do. However its not really effective when you are free diving (waste of energyoxygen to move your arms up and down to the face every 2-3m) so what most freedivers do is either use a really strong nose clip that will equalise their ears when they try and blow out their nose or jaw wriggling technique (I personally haven't mastered this one) Source: scuba instructor and free dive as a hobby

There are many ways to equalize your ears when you dive. The most common method is to pinch your nose, and you might expect this is what people do. However, this method isn't very effective for free diving. It takes a lot of energy and oxygen to move your arms to your face every few meters. Instead, most freedivers use a strong nose clip to help equalize their ears when they try to blow out their nose. Some also use a jaw-wiggling technique, but I haven't learned that one yet.

Your eye is not a sphere. The lens sticks out from the eyeball, and contacts are fit to that shape.', "Your eye isn't a neat spherical shape. The cornea forms a bulge that juts forward from the front of the eye. Contact lenses are shaped to fit snugly over this bulge, which means they don't fit properly on the rest of the eyeball. So if they get jarred out of position, they'll slide around on the eye until they find their way back into position on the bulge again.

Your eye is not a perfect sphere. The front part of your eye, called the cornea, sticks out. Contact lenses are designed to fit over this bump. Because of this shape, the lenses don't fit evenly on the rest of the eye. If they move out of place, they can slide around until they settle back on the bulge.

Not a biologist, but how it's been explained to me: Whenever a cell reproduces, the DNA replicates. However, DNA replication is imperfect, and you usually wind up losing some off the ends of the DNA strands. At the end of each strand of DNA are telomeres, which are basically useless bits of genetic code. They serve as kind of a buffer in the replication. As you age, the telomeres get shorter due to imperfect replication, and then once you start losing relevant DNA is when you start to have major bodily breakdowns.

I'm not a biologist, but here's what I've learned: When a cell divides, it copies its DNA. This process isn't perfect, and some parts of the DNA get lost at the ends. The ends of DNA strands are called telomeres. They are extra bits of genetic code that don't really do anything. They act like a cushion during copying. As we get older, the telomeres become shorter because of these copying mistakes. When the telomeres get too short and we start losing important DNA, our bodies begin to break down.

I'm not a biologist, but here's what I understand: When a cell divides, it makes a copy of its DNA. This copying isn't perfect, and some DNA can be lost at the ends. The ends of DNA strands are called telomeres. Telomeres are extra pieces of DNA that don't have a specific function. They help protect the important parts during copying. As we age, telomeres get shorter because of these copying errors. When telomeres become too short and we start losing important DNA, our bodies begin to weaken.

Batteries (or cells if you're pedantic) work by a chemical reaction between two different electrodes. Once the reaction has progressed as far as it can, the battery is discharged. Chargers reverse the chemical reaction by applying a higher voltage to the cell than the cell generates on its own. When the battery is fully charged, the charger must stop or it will start to release gas and damage the cell. Charge termination detection is different for different types of cells.
The way to know when to stop charging varies for different types of batteries.
Different types of batteries have different ways to tell when to stop charging.
Different types of batteries have different methods to indicate when they are fully charged.

Whenever your muscles move they produce some heat. This is something you can not avoid as a lot of the muscles that move are essential to survive, like your heart, lung, controlling blood flow, digestive system, etc. Normally your body will regulate the heat to steady levels. However if it is hot outside, you lack water, you are ill, etc. then you may have problems regulating your body temperature. And the body temperature is not that far off the temperature at which proteins will start to unravel. So if your body temperature goes too high the proteins will not be able to do their job and body functions will stop.

When your muscles move, they create heat. This is unavoidable because many important muscles, like your heart and those that help with breathing and digestion, are always working. Usually, your body keeps this heat at a steady level. But if it’s hot outside, if you don’t have enough water, or if you are sick, it can be hard for your body to control its temperature. If your body temperature gets too high, it can cause proteins to break down. When this happens, the proteins can’t work properly, and your body functions can stop.

In this work we investigate energy efficient packet scheduling problem for the loss tolerant applications. We consider slow fading channel for a point to point connection with no channel state information at the transmitter side (CSIT). In the absence of CSIT, the slow fading channel has an outage probability associated with every transmit power. As a function of data loss tolerance parameters and peak power constraints, we formulate an optimization problem to minimize the average transmit energy for the user equipment (UE). The optimization problem is not convex and we use stochastic optimization technique to solve the problem. The numerical results quantify the effect of different system parameters on average transmit power and show significant power savings for the loss tolerant applications.

Our numerical results show how different system settings affect the average transmit power and demonstrate that there can be significant energy savings for applications that can handle some data loss.

We introduce and investigate a new notion of resilience in graph spanners. Let S be a spanner of a graph G . Roughly speaking, we say that a spanner S is resilient if all its point-to-point distances are resilient to edge failures. Namely, whenever any edge in G fails, then as a consequence of this failure all distances do not degrade in S substantially more than in G (i.e., the relative distance increases in S are very close to those in the underlying graph G). In this paper we show that sparse resilient spanners exist, and that they can be computed efficiently.

We present a new idea about resilience in graph spanners. Let S be a spanner of a graph G. We define a spanner S as resilient if its distances between points remain stable even when edges in G fail. This means that when an edge in G fails, the distances in S do not increase significantly more than those in G. In other words, the increase in distances in S is similar to the increase in distances in G. In this paper, we demonstrate that there are sparse resilient spanners, and we show that they can be computed quickly.

We have a new idea about resilience in graph spanners. Let S be a spanner of a graph G. We say that S is resilient if the distances between points stay stable when edges in G fail. This means that when an edge in G fails, the distances in S do not increase much more than those in G. In simpler terms, if distances in G go up, distances in S should go up by a similar amount. In this paper, we show that there are sparse resilient spanners, and we explain how to compute them quickly.

In other words, if distances in G increase, distances in S should also increase by a similar amount. We analyze the complexity of biased stochastic gradient methods (SGD), where individual updates are corrupted by deterministic, i.e. biased error terms. We derive convergence results for smooth (non-convex) functions and give improved rates under the Polyak-ojasiewicz condition. We quantify how the magnitude of the bias impacts the attainable accuracy and convergence rates. Our framework covers many applications where either only biased gradient updates are available or preferred over unbiased ones for performance reasons. For instance, in the domain of distributed learning, biased gradient compression techniques such as top- k compression have been proposed as a tool to alleviate the communication bottleneck and in derivative-free optimization, only biased gradient estimators can be queried. We discuss a few guiding examples that show the broad applicability of our analysis.

We study biased stochastic gradient methods (SGD), where each update is affected by fixed errors. We find results on how quickly these methods can converge for smooth (non-convex) functions and show better rates when certain conditions are met. We also explain how the size of the bias affects the accuracy and speed of convergence. Our findings apply to many situations where only biased gradient updates are used or preferred for better performance. For example, in distributed learning, biased gradient compression techniques, like top-k compression, help reduce communication issues. In derivative-free optimization, only biased gradient estimators can be used. We provide examples to illustrate the wide range of applications for our analysis.

We present a novel algorithm for instrumental variable (IV) regression, DualIV, which simplifies traditional two-stage methods via a dual formulation. Inspired by problems in stochastic programming, we show that the two-stage procedure for nonlinear IV regression can be reformulated as a convex-concave saddle-point problem. Our formulation circumvents the first-stage regression which is a potential bottleneck in real-world applications. Based on this new approach, we develop a simple kernel-based algorithm with a closed-form solution. Empirical results show that we are competitive to existing, more complicated algorithms for instrumental variable regression.

We have created a new algorithm for instrumental variable (IV) regression called DualIV. This algorithm makes traditional two-stage methods easier to use. It is based on ideas from stochastic programming. We demonstrate that the two-stage process for nonlinear IV regression can be changed into a convex-concave saddle-point problem. This new method avoids the first-stage regression, which can be a major obstacle in real-world situations. Using this approach, we developed a straightforward kernel-based algorithm that has a clear solution. Our tests show that our algorithm performs well compared to existing, more complex IV regression algorithms.

With this approach, we created a simple kernel-based algorithm that provides a clear solution. Our tests indicate that our algorithm works well compared to existing, more complicated IV regression methods.

We explore the design of an effective crowdsourcing system for an M -ary classification task. Crowd workers complete simple binary microtasks whose results are aggregated to give the final decision. We consider the scenario where the workers have a reject option so that they are allowed to skip microtasks when they are unable to or choose not to respond to binary microtasks. We present an aggregation approach using a weighted majority voting rule, where each worker's response is assigned an optimized weight to maximize crowd's classification performance.

We also allow workers to skip tasks if they cannot or do not want to answer. To combine the workers' answers, we use a method called weighted majority voting. This means each worker's answer is given a specific weight to improve the overall accuracy of the classification.

Levin defined a real number x that satisfies that the sequence of the fractional parts of ( 2 n x) n 1 are such that the first N terms have discrepancy O ( (log N) 2 N), which is the smallest discrepancy known for this kind of parametric sequences. In this work we show that the fractional parts of the sequence ( 2 n x) n 1 fail to have Poissonian pair correlations. This is the smallest difference found for these types of sequences. In our study, we show that the fractional parts of the sequence \( (2^n x)_{n=1} \) do not have Poissonian pair correlations. We also prove that any real numbers \( x \) that are variations of Levin's number, made using Pascal triangle matrices, also do not have Poissonian pair correlations.

In our study, we show that the fractional parts of the sequence \( (2^n x)_{n=1} \) do not show Poissonian pair correlations. We also prove that any real numbers \( x \) that are variations of Levin's number, created using Pascal triangle matrices, also do not have Poissonian pair correlations.

We propose a novel measure to quantify dismantlement of a fragmented network. The existing measure of dismantlement used to study problems like optimal percolation is usually the size of the largest component of the network. We modify the measure of uniformity used to prove the Szemeredi's Regularity Lemma to obtain the proposed measure. The proposed measure incorporates the notion that the measure of dismantlement increases as the number of disconnected components increase and decreases as the variance of sizes of these components increases.

We suggest a new way to measure how a broken network falls apart. Currently, the common method looks at the size of the largest part of the network. We change a method called uniformity, which was used to support Szemeredi's Regularity Lemma, to create our new measure. Our measure considers that dismantlement grows when more parts of the network are disconnected and shrinks when the sizes of these parts vary more.

We have changed a method called uniformity, which was used in Szemeredi's Regularity Lemma, to create our new measure. Our measure shows that the breakdown increases when more parts of the network are disconnected. It decreases when the sizes of these parts are very different from each other.

Industry 4.0 is becoming more and more important for manufacturers as the developments in the area of Internet of Things advance. Another technology gaining more attention is data stream processing systems. Although such streaming frameworks seem to be a natural fit for Industry 4.0 scenarios, their application in this context is still low. The contributions in this paper are threefold. Firstly, we present industry findings that we derived from site inspections with a focus on Industry 4.0. Moreover, our view on Industry 4.0 and important related aspects is elaborated. As a third contribution, we illustrate our opinion on why data stream processing technologies could act as an enabler for Industry 4.0 and point out possible obstacles on this way.

This paper has three main contributions. First, we share findings from our visits to various industries, focusing on Industry 4.0. Second, we explain our perspective on Industry 4.0 and its key aspects. Finally, we discuss how data stream processing technologies could help advance Industry 4.0 and highlight some challenges that may arise.

Finally, we talk about how data stream processing technologies can help improve Industry 4.0 and mention some challenges that might come up.

Network densification and heterogenisation through the deployment of small cellular access points (picocells and femtocells) are seen as key mechanisms in handling the exponential increase in cellular data traffic. Modelling such networks by leveraging tools from Stochastic Geometry has proven particularly useful in understanding the fundamental limits imposed on network coverage and capacity by co-channel interference. Most of these works however assume infinite sized and uniformly distributed networks on the Euclidean plane. In contrast, we study finite sized non-uniformly distributed networks, and find the optimal non-uniform distribution of access points which maximises network coverage for a given non-uniform distribution of mobile users, and vice versa .

To manage the rapid growth of cellular data traffic, adding more small cellular access points, like picocells and femtocells, is important. Using Stochastic Geometry helps us model these networks and understand how interference affects coverage and capacity. Most studies focus on large, evenly spread networks. In our research, we look at smaller, unevenly distributed networks. We aim to find the best way to place access points to improve network coverage based on where mobile users are located, and to optimize the distribution of users based on where the access points are.

To handle the fast increase in cellular data traffic, it’s important to add more small access points, such as picocells and femtocells. We use Stochastic Geometry to model these networks and see how interference impacts coverage and capacity. Most research looks at large, evenly spread networks. In our study, we focus on smaller networks that are not evenly distributed. Our goal is to find the best places to put access points to improve network coverage based on where mobile users are. We also want to optimize where users are located in relation to the access points.

Many continuous control tasks have bounded action spaces. When policy gradient methods are applied to such tasks, out-of-bound actions need to be clipped before execution, while policies are usually optimized as if the actions are not clipped. We propose a policy gradient estimator that exploits the knowledge of actions being clipped to reduce the variance in estimation. We prove that our estimator, named clipped action policy gradient (CAPG), is unbiased and achieves lower variance than the conventional estimator that ignores action bounds. Experimental results demonstrate that CAPG generally outperforms the conventional estimator, indicating that it is a better policy gradient estimator for continuous control tasks. We study the metric facility location problem with client insertions and deletions. This setting differs from the classic dynamic facility location problem, where the set of clients remains the same, but the metric space can change over time. We show a deterministic algorithm that maintains a constant factor approximation to the optimal solution in worst-case time O (2 O ( 2 per client insertion or deletion in metric spaces while answering queries about the cost in O (1) time, where denotes the doubling dimension of the metric. For metric spaces with bounded doubling dimension, the update time is polylogarithmic in the parameters of the problem.

We present a deterministic algorithm that keeps a consistent approximation of the best solution, even in the worst case. The time taken for each client to be added or removed is O(2^(O(2))), depending on the metric space, and it can answer cost queries in O(1) time. Here, the doubling dimension of the metric is important. For metric spaces with a limited doubling dimension, the time for updates is polylogarithmic in relation to the problem parameters.

We have created a reliable algorithm that always provides a good estimate of the best solution, even in the worst situations. Adding or removing a client takes time proportional to O(2^(O(2))), which depends on the type of metric space. However, it can answer cost questions very quickly, in O(1) time. The doubling dimension of the metric space plays a key role here. For metric spaces with a small doubling dimension, the time for updates is much faster and grows at a polylogarithmic rate compared to the problem parameters.

We have developed a dependable algorithm that consistently gives a good estimate of the best solution, even in tough situations. When we add or remove a client, it takes a significant amount of time, which is about O(2^(O(2))) and varies based on the type of metric space. However, the algorithm can quickly answer cost questions in O(1) time. The doubling dimension of the metric space is very important in this process. For metric spaces with a small doubling dimension, the time for updates is much quicker and increases at a slower rate compared to the problem parameters.

We created a reliable algorithm that reliably finds a good solution, even in difficult cases. When we add or remove a client, it takes a lot of time, roughly O(2^(O(2))), and this depends on the type of metric space. However, the algorithm can quickly answer cost questions in O(1) time. The doubling dimension of the metric space is crucial here. For metric spaces with a small doubling dimension, updates happen much faster and increase more slowly compared to the problem's parameters.

We study two types of preconditioners and preconditioned stochastic gradient descent (SGD) methods in a unified framework. We call the first one the Newton type due to its close relationship to Newton method, and the second one the Fisher type as its preconditioner is closely related to the inverse of Fisher information matrix. Both preconditioners can be derived from one framework, and efficiently learned on any matrix Lie groups designated by the user using natural or relative gradient descent. Many existing preconditioners and methods are special cases of either the Newton type or the Fisher type ones. Experimental results on relatively large scale machine learning problems are reported for performance study.

We examine two types of preconditioners and their use in preconditioned stochastic gradient descent (SGD) methods. The first type is called the Newton type because it is similar to the Newton method. The second type is called the Fisher type because its preconditioner is related to the inverse of the Fisher information matrix. Both types can be developed from a common framework and can be effectively learned on any matrix Lie groups chosen by the user using natural or relative gradient descent. Many existing preconditioners and methods fall under either the Newton type or the Fisher type. We also present experimental results on larger machine learning problems to evaluate their performance.

The second type is called the Fisher type because it is based on the inverse of the Fisher information matrix. Both types can be created from a common framework and can be effectively learned using natural or relative gradient descent on any matrix Lie groups chosen by the user. Many existing preconditioners and methods are either Newton type or Fisher type. We also share experimental results on larger machine learning problems to see how well they perform.

This paper presents RIMAX, a new system for detecting semantic rhymes, using a Comprehensive Mexican Spanish Dictionary (DEM) and its Rhyming Dictionary (REM). We use the Vector Space Model to calculate the similarity of the definition of a query with the definitions corresponding to the assonant and consonant rhymes of the query. The preliminary results using a manual evaluation are very encouraging.

This paper introduces RIMAX, a new system for finding semantic rhymes. It uses a Comprehensive Mexican Spanish Dictionary (DEM) and a Rhyming Dictionary (REM). We calculate how similar the definition of a query is to the definitions of assonant and consonant rhymes using the Vector Space Model. The early results from manual evaluations are very promising.

This paper presents RIMAX, a new system for finding rhymes that have similar meanings. It uses a Comprehensive Mexican Spanish Dictionary (DEM) and a Rhyming Dictionary (REM). We compare the meaning of a query with the meanings of rhymes that sound alike using a method called the Vector Space Model. The initial results from manual checks look very promising.

This paper introduces RIMAX, a new system for finding rhymes with similar meanings. It uses the Comprehensive Mexican Spanish Dictionary (DEM) and a Rhyming Dictionary (REM). We compare the meaning of a given word with the meanings of rhymes that sound similar using a technique called the Vector Space Model. The first results from manual checks seem very promising.

We compare the meaning of a word to the meanings of rhyming words that sound alike using a method called the Vector Space Model. The initial results from our checks look very promising.

We present a game semantics for Linear Logic, in which formulas denote games and proofs denote winning strategies. We show that our semantics yields a categorical model of Linear Logic and prove full completeness for Multiplicative Linear Logic with the MIX rule: every winning strategy is the denotation of a unique cut-free proof net. A key role is played by the notion of history-free strategy; strong connections are made between history-free strategies and the Geometry of Interaction. Our semantics incorporates a natural notion of polarity, leading to a refined treatment of the additives. We make comparisons with related work by Joyal, Blass et al .

A key concept in our work is the history-free strategy. We find strong links between these strategies and the Geometry of Interaction. Our approach also includes a clear idea of polarity, which helps us better understand the additive components of Linear Logic. Finally, we compare our work to related research by Joyal, Blass, and others.

Our approach also emphasizes polarity, which helps us understand the parts of Linear Logic better. Lastly, we compare our work to research done by Joyal, Blass, and others.

Clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata extend classical timed automata with discrete probabilistic choice, where the probabilities are allowed to depend on the exact values of the clocks. Previous work has shown that the quantitative reachability problem for clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata with at least three clocks is undecidable. In this paper, we consider the subclass of clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata that have one clock , that have clock dependencies described by affine functions, and that satisfy an initialisation condition requiring that, at some point between taking edges with non-trivial clock dependencies, the clock must have an integer value. We present an approach for solving in polynomial time quantitative and qualitative reachability problems of such one-clock initialised clock-dependent probabilistic timed automata. Our results are obtained by a transformation to interval Markov decision processes.

We present a method to solve both quantitative and qualitative reachability problems for these one-clock models in polynomial time. Our results come from transforming the problem into interval Markov decision processes.

Although we have tons of machine learning tools to analyze data, most of them require users have some programming backgrounds. Here we introduce a SaaS application which allows users analyze their data without any coding and even without any knowledge of machine learning. Users can upload, train, predict and download their data by simply clicks their mouses. Our system uses data pre-processor and validator to relieve the computational cost of our server. The simple architecture of Vanlearning helps developers can easily maintain and extend it.

We demonstrate the capabilities of nonlinear Volterra models to simulate the behavior of an audio system and compare them to linear filters. In this paper a nonlinear model of an audio system based on Volterra series is presented and Normalized Least Mean Square algorithm is used to determine the Volterra series to third order. Training data for the models were collected measuring a physical speaker using a laser interferometer. We explore several training signals and filter's parameters. Results indicate a decrease in Mean Squared Error compared to the linear model with a dependency on the particular test signal, the order and the parameters of the model.

We show how nonlinear Volterra models can simulate an audio system and compare them to linear filters. This paper introduces a nonlinear model of an audio system using Volterra series. We use the Normalized Least Mean Square algorithm to find the third-order Volterra series. To train the models, we collected data by measuring a physical speaker with a laser interferometer. We tested different training signals and filter parameters. The results show that the Mean Squared Error is lower with the nonlinear model than with the linear model. However, this improvement depends on the specific test signal, the model's order, and its parameters.

In a function approximation with a neural network, an input dataset is mapped to an output index by optimizing the parameters of each hidden-layer unit. For a unary function, we present constraints on the parameters and its second derivative by constructing a continuum version of a one-hidden-layer neural network with the rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation function. The network is accurately implemented because the constraints decrease the degrees of freedom of the parameters. We also explain the existence of a smooth binary function that cannot be precisely represented by any such neural network.

In a neural network used for function approximation, we connect an input dataset to an output index by adjusting the settings of each hidden layer unit. For a single-variable function, we show how to set limits on the parameters and the second derivative by creating a continuous version of a one-hidden-layer neural network that uses the rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation function. This network works well because the limits reduce the number of free parameters we can change. We also discuss that there is a smooth binary function that cannot be exactly represented by any neural network of this type.

We do this by creating a continuous version of a one-hidden-layer neural network that uses the rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation function. This approach is effective because the limits reduce the number of adjustable parameters. We also mention that there is a smooth binary function that cannot be exactly represented by this type of neural network.

Neuro-symbolic and statistical relational artificial intelligence both integrate frameworks for learning with logical reasoning. This survey identifies several parallels across seven different dimensions between these two fields. These cannot only be used to characterize and position neuro-symbolic artificial intelligence approaches but also to identify a number of directions for further research.

We propose a deep neural network framework for computing prices and deltas of American options in high dimensions. The architecture of the framework is a sequence of neural networks, where each network learns the difference of the price functions between adjacent timesteps. We introduce the least squares residual of the associated backward stochastic differential equation as the loss function. Our proposed framework yields prices and deltas on the entire spacetime, not only at a given point. The computational cost of the proposed approach is quadratic in dimension, which addresses the curse of dimensionality issue that state-of-the-art approaches suffer. Our numerical simulations demonstrate these contributions, and show that the proposed neural network framework outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in high dimensions.

We suggest a new method using deep neural networks to calculate the prices and deltas of American options in high dimensions. Our method consists of a series of neural networks. Each network learns the price differences between two time steps. We use the least squares residual from a related backward stochastic differential equation as our loss function. This approach allows us to get prices and deltas for the entire spacetime, not just at one point. The computational cost is quadratic in relation to the dimensions, which helps solve the problem of high dimensions that other methods struggle with. Our tests show that our neural network method performs better than current leading methods in high dimensions.

Each network learns the price changes between two time steps. We use the least squares residual from a related backward stochastic differential equation as our loss function. This lets us find prices and deltas for the entire spacetime, not just at one point. The computational cost increases with the square of the dimensions, which helps address the challenges of high dimensions that other methods face. Our tests show that our neural network method works better than the leading methods in high dimensions.

Although the computation cost increases with the square of the dimensions, our method helps us avoid problems that other methods face in high dimensions. Our tests show that our neural network method works better than the best existing methods in these high dimensions.

Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) with their dynamic applications gained a tremendous attention of researchers. Constant monitoring of critical situations attracted researchers to utilize WSNs at vast platforms. The main focus in WSNs is to enhance network life-time as much as one could, for efficient and optimal utilization of resources. Different approaches based upon clustering are proposed for optimum functionality. Network life-time is always related with energy of sensor nodes deployed at remote areas for constant and fault tolerant monitoring. In this work, we propose Quadrature-LEACH (Q-LEACH) for homogenous networks which enhances stability period, network life-time and throughput quiet significantly.

Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) have become very popular among researchers because of their many uses. Researchers are interested in using WSNs to monitor important situations continuously. The main goal in WSNs is to extend the network's life as much as possible to use resources efficiently. Various clustering methods have been suggested to improve performance. The life of the network depends on the energy of the sensor nodes placed in remote areas for ongoing and reliable monitoring. In this work, we introduce Quadrature-LEACH (Q-LEACH) for networks with the same type of sensors. This method significantly improves the stability period, network life, and overall performance.

This research paper proposes a COVID-19 monitoring and response system to identify the surge in the volume of patients at hospitals and shortage of critical equipment like ventilators in South-east Asian countries, to understand the burden on health facilities. This can help authorities in these regions with resource planning measures to redirect resources to the regions identified by the model. Due to the lack of publicly available data on the influx of patients in hospitals, or the shortage of equipment, ICU units or hospital beds that regions in these countries might be facing, we leverage Twitter data for gleaning this information. The approach has yielded accurate results for states in India, and we are working on validating the model for the remaining countries so that it can serve as a reliable tool for authorities to monitor the burden on hospitals.

Since there isn't much public data on hospital patient numbers or equipment shortages in these countries, we use Twitter data to gather this information. Our method has worked well in India, and we are now testing it in other countries to make sure it is reliable. This system can help authorities keep an eye on hospital needs during the pandemic.

We present a PTAS for agnostically learning halfspaces w.r.t. the uniform distribution on the d dimensional sphere. Namely, we show that for every 0 there is an algorithm that runs in time poly (d , 1 ), and is guaranteed to return a classifier with error at most ( 1 ) opt , where opt is the error of the best halfspace classifier. This improves on Awasthi, Balcan and Long who showed an algorithm with an (unspecified) constant approximation ratio. Our algorithm combines the classical technique of polynomial regression (e.g.), together with the new localization technique of .

We present a new algorithm that can learn halfspaces effectively under a uniform distribution on a d-dimensional sphere. Specifically, for any small value \( \epsilon > 0 \), our algorithm runs in polynomial time based on the dimensions \( d \) and \( 1/\epsilon \). It guarantees that the classifier it produces will have an error that is at most \( (1 + \epsilon) \) times the error of the best possible halfspace classifier. This is an improvement over the work of Awasthi, Balcan, and Long, who provided an algorithm with a constant approximation ratio that was not specified. Our approach combines the well-known method of polynomial regression with a new technique called localization.

Our method combines the well-known technique of polynomial regression with a new approach called localization.

We explain how recent developments in the fields of Realisability models for linear logic - or geometry of interaction - and implicit computational complexity can lead to a new approach of implicit computational complexity. This semantic-based approach should apply uniformly to various computational paradigms, and enable the use of new mathematical methods and tools to attack problem in computational complexity. This paper provides the background, motivations and perspectives of this complexity-through-Realisability theory to be developed, and illustrates it with recent results .

We discuss how new ideas in Realisability models for linear logic and implicit computational complexity can create a fresh way to understand implicit computational complexity. This new approach focuses on meaning and should work well across different types of computation. It will also allow us to use new math methods and tools to solve problems in computational complexity. This paper explains the background, reasons, and future outlook for this theory of complexity through Realisability. We also show recent results to illustrate our points.

This paper covers the background, reasons, and future possibilities for this theory of complexity through Realisability. We also present recent results to support our ideas.

We investigate whether off-the-shelf deep bidirectional sentence representations trained on a massively multilingual corpus (multilingual BERT) enable the development of an unsupervised universal dependency parser. This approach only leverages a mix of monolingual corpora in many languages and does not require any translation data making it applicable to low-resource languages. In our experiments we outperform the best CoNLL 2018 language-specific systems in all of the shared task's six truly low-resource languages while using a single system. However, we also find that (i) parsing accuracy still varies dramatically when changing the training languages and (ii) in some target languages zero-shot transfer fails under all tested conditions, raising concerns on the 'universality' of the whole approach.

In our tests, we did better than the best systems from the CoNLL 2018 competition in all six low-resource languages. We achieved this with just one system. However, we also discovered two important things: (i) the accuracy of parsing changes a lot depending on the training languages used, and (ii) in some target languages, our method does not work at all under certain conditions. This raises questions about how universal our approach really is.

In our tests, we performed better than the best systems from the CoNLL 2018 competition in all six low-resource languages, using just one system. However, we found two important things: (i) the accuracy of parsing varies greatly based on the training languages we used, and (ii) in some target languages, our method does not work at all in certain situations. This makes us question how universal our approach is.

This raises questions about how universal our approach really is.

In the article Recursive queries on trees and data trees (ICDT'13), Abiteboul et al. asked whether the containment problem for monadic datalog over unordered unranked labeled trees using the child relation and the descendant relation is decidable. This note gives a positive answer to this question, as well as an overview of the relative expressive power of monadic datalog on various representations of unranked trees.

In the article "Recursive Queries on Trees and Data Trees" (ICDT'13), Abiteboul and others asked if we can decide if one query contains another for a specific kind of tree structure. This structure is called a monadic datalog and uses child and descendant relationships in unordered, unranked labeled trees. This note answers that question positively. It also provides an overview of how powerful monadic datalog is when applied to different types of unranked trees.

In the article "Recursive Queries on Trees and Data Trees" (ICDT'13), Abiteboul and others explored whether we can determine if one query is included in another for a specific type of tree structure. This type is called monadic datalog, which looks at child and descendant relationships in unordered, unranked labeled trees. This note confirms that we can indeed make that decision. It also explains how effective monadic datalog is when used with different kinds of unranked trees.

They wanted to know if we can tell if one query is part of another for a type of tree called monadic datalog. This type focuses on relationships between children and descendants in trees that do not have a specific order or ranking. This note confirms that we can decide if one query is included in another. It also shows how well monadic datalog works with different kinds of unranked trees.

With the increasing importance of data privacy protection, federated learning is becoming more widely used, and there are more frameworks for federated learning. However, the centralization of federated learning has always restricted the development of federated learning and the federated learning framework. Although there are some decentralized federated learning algorithms, these algorithms have some shortcomings and there is no framework that can quickly use these algorithms. In this paper,we proposed and implemented a blockchain-based decentralized federated learning framework called GFL (,) and integrated two new blockchain-based decentralized federated learning mechanisms to try to try to make the decentralized federated learning algorithm better landed.

As data privacy becomes more important, federated learning is being used more often, and more frameworks are being developed for it. However, the centralization of federated learning has limited its growth. There are some decentralized federated learning algorithms, but they have drawbacks, and there isn't a framework that makes them easy to use. In this paper, we propose and implement a new decentralized federated learning framework called GFL, which is based on blockchain technology. We also introduce two new blockchain-based mechanisms to improve the use of decentralized federated learning algorithms.

While there are some decentralized federated learning algorithms, they have issues, and no user-friendly framework exists for them. In this paper, we propose and implement a new decentralized federated learning framework called GFL, which uses blockchain technology. We also introduce two new blockchain-based methods to enhance the use of decentralized federated learning algorithms.

There are some decentralized federated learning algorithms, but they have problems, and there isn’t an easy-to-use framework for them. In this paper, we present a new decentralized federated learning framework called GFL that uses blockchain technology. We also introduce two new methods based on blockchain to improve decentralized federated learning algorithms.

Data privacy is very important today, so federated learning is becoming more popular. However, the typical way federated learning is set up is too centralized, which slows its progress. There are some decentralized federated learning methods, but they have issues, and there isn’t a simple framework for them. In this paper, we introduce a new decentralized federated learning framework called GFL that uses blockchain technology. We also present two new methods using blockchain to enhance decentralized federated learning algorithms.

In a guessing game, players guess the value of a random real number selected using some probability density function. The winner may be determined in various ways; for example, a winner can be a player whose guess is closest in magnitude to the target or a winner can be a player coming closest without guessing higher than the target. We study optimal strategies for players in these games and determine some of them for two, three, and four players.

In a guessing game, players try to guess a random number chosen based on a probability rule. There are different ways to decide who wins. One way is to choose the player whose guess is the closest to the actual number. Another way is to pick the player whose guess is closest without going over the number. We look at the best strategies for players in these games and find some strategies for two, three, and four players.

The earliest extant samples of connected (north) Estonian are the so-called Kullamaa prayers dating from 1524 and 1528. In 1525 the first book published in the Estonian language was printed. The Tito-Stalin split had large ramifications for countries outside the USSR and Yugoslavia. It has, for example, been given as one of the reasons for the Slansky trial in Czechoslovakia, in which 14 high-level Communist officials were purged, with 11 of them being executed. Stalin put pressure on Czechoslovakia to conduct purges in order to discourage the spread of the idea of a "national path to socialism," which Tito espoused.

The split between Tito and Stalin had a big impact on countries outside the USSR and Yugoslavia. One example is the Slansky trial in Czechoslovakia. In this trial, 14 high-ranking Communist officials were removed from power, and 11 of them were executed. Stalin pressured Czechoslovakia to carry out these purges to stop the idea of a "national path to socialism," which Tito supported.

The split between Tito and Stalin affected many countries beyond the USSR and Yugoslavia. One example is the Slansky trial in Czechoslovakia. Some people consider glass to be a liquid due to its lack of a first-order phase transition where certain thermodynamic variables such as volume, entropy and enthalpy are discontinuous through the glass transition range. The glass transition may be described as analogous to a second-order phase transition where the intensive thermodynamic variables such as the thermal expansivity and heat capacity are discontinuous. Nonetheless, the equilibrium theory of phase transformations does not entirely hold for glass, and hence the glass transition cannot be classed as one of the classical equilibrium phase transformations in solids.

Some people think of glass as a liquid because it doesn't show a clear change in certain properties, like volume and heat, when it goes through the glass transition. This transition is similar to a second-order phase change, where some properties, like how much the material expands with heat, change suddenly. However, the usual theories about phase changes don't fully apply to glass. So, the glass transition isn't considered a typical phase change like those in solid materials.

Eritrea can be split into three ecoregions. To the east of the highlands are the hot, arid coastal plains stretching down to the southeast of the country. The cooler, more fertile highlands, reaching up to 3000m has a different habitat. Habitats here vary from the sub-tropical rainforest at Filfil Solomona to the precipitous cliffs and canyons of the southern highlands. The Afar Triangle or Danakil Depression of Eritrea is the probable location of a triple junction where three tectonic plates are pulling away from one another.The highest point of the country, Emba Soira, is located in the center of Eritrea, at 3,018 meters (9,902 ft) above sea level.

Eritrea has three main ecoregions. To the east, there are hot and dry coastal plains that extend to the southeast. The highlands are cooler and more fertile, reaching heights of up to 3,000 meters. The habitats here are diverse, including subtropical rainforests at Filfil Solomona and steep cliffs and canyons in the southern highlands. The Afar Triangle, also known as the Danakil Depression, is where three tectonic plates are moving apart. The highest point in Eritrea is Emba Soira, which is 3,018 meters (9,902 feet) above sea level and located in the center of the country.

The Enlightenment has been frequently linked to the French Revolution of 1789. One view of the political changes that occurred during the Enlightenment is that the "consent of the governed" philosophy as delineated by Locke in Two Treatises of Government (1689) represented a paradigm shift from the old governance paradigm under feudalism known as the "divine right of kings." In this view, the revolutions of the late 1700s and early 1800s were caused by the fact that this governance paradigm shift often could not be resolved peacefully, and therefore violent revolution was the result. Clearly a governance philosophy where the king was never wrong was in direct conflict with one whereby citizens by natural law had to consent to the acts and rulings of their government.

The Enlightenment is often connected to the French Revolution of 1789. One important idea from this period is the "consent of the governed," explained by John Locke in his work, *Two Treatises of Government* (1689). This idea marked a big change from the old way of ruling, where kings believed they had the "divine right" to govern. Many revolutions in the late 1700s and early 1800s happened because this shift in thinking could not always be resolved peacefully. As a result, people sometimes turned to violent rebellion. The idea that a king could do no wrong directly clashed with the belief that citizens have a natural right to agree to the actions of their government.

The Enlightenment is often linked to the French Revolution of 1789. One key idea from this time is "consent of the governed," which John Locke wrote about in *Two Treatises of Government* (1689). This idea was a big change from the old belief that kings had a "divine right" to rule. Many revolutions in the late 1700s and early 1800s happened because people struggled to accept this new way of thinking peacefully. As a result, some turned to violent rebellion. The belief that a king could do no wrong clashed with the idea that citizens should have a say in their government.

Title IV of the 1978 Spanish constitution invests the Consentimiento Real (Royal Assent) and promulgation (publication) of laws with the monarch of Spain, while Title III, The Cortes Generales, Chapter 2, Drafting of Bills, outlines the method by which bills are passed. According to Article 91, within fifteen days of passage of a bill by the Cortes Generales, the sovereign shall give his or her assent and publish the new law. Article 92 invests the monarch with the right to call for a referendum, on the advice of the president of the government (commonly referred to in English as the prime minister) and the authorisation of the cortes.

Title IV of the 1978 Spanish Constitution gives the King of Spain the power to approve and publish laws. Title III, which is about the Cortes Generales (the Spanish Parliament), explains how laws are created. Article 91 states that within fifteen days after the Cortes Generales passes a bill, the King must either approve it and publish it as law. Article 92 allows the King to call for a referendum if the prime minister advises him and the Cortes gives permission.

Article 91 says that the King must approve a bill and publish it as law within fifteen days after the Cortes Generales passes it. Article 92 lets the King call for a referendum if the prime minister recommends it and the Cortes agrees.

Metro Detroit has an extensive toll-free network of freeways administered by the Michigan Department of Transportation. Four major Interstate Highways surround the city. Detroit is connected via Interstate 75 (I-75) and I-96 to Kings Highway 401 and to major Southern Ontario cities such as London, Ontario and the Greater Toronto Area. I-75 (Chrysler and Fisher freeways) is the region's main north-south route, serving Flint, Pontiac, Troy, and Detroit, before continuing south (as the Detroit-Toledo and Seaway Freeways) to serve many of the communities along the shore of Lake Erie.

It connects Flint, Pontiac, Troy, and Detroit, and then continues south as the Detroit-Toledo and Seaway Freeways. These freeways serve many communities along Lake Erie.

The astronomer Aristarchus of Samos was the first known person to propose a heliocentric model of the solar system, while the geographer Eratosthenes accurately calculated the circumference of the Earth. Hipparchus (c. 190 - c. 120 BC) produced the first systematic star catalog. The level of achievement in Hellenistic astronomy and engineering is impressively shown by the Antikythera mechanism (150-100 BC), an analog computer for calculating the position of planets. Technological artifacts of similar complexity did not reappear until the 14th century, when mechanical astronomical clocks appeared in Europe.

Aristarchus of Samos was the first person we know of to suggest that the Sun is at the center of the solar system. Eratosthenes, a geographer, was able to calculate the Earth's circumference accurately. Hipparchus, who lived around 190 to 120 BC, created the first organized star catalog. The Antikythera mechanism, built between 150 and 100 BC, shows how advanced Hellenistic astronomy and engineering were. This device was an early analog computer used to calculate the positions of planets. Similar complex technology did not appear again until the 14th century, when mechanical astronomical clocks were made in Europe.

In the light of Mother F. A. Forbes research and reference to Pope Saint Gregory's writings, it would appear that Athanasius was constrained to be Bishop: She writes that when the Patriarch Alexander was on his death-bed he called Athanasius, who fled fearing he would be constrained to be made Bishop. "When the Bishops of the Church assembled to elect their new Patriarch, the whole Catholic population surrounded the church, holding up their hands to Heaven and crying; "Give us Athanasius!" The Bishops had nothing better. Athanasius was thus elected, as Gregory tells us..." (Pope Gregory I, would have full access to the Vatican Archives).

According to Mother F. A. Forbes' research and the writings of Pope Saint Gregory, Athanasius did not want to be Bishop but was forced into the role. She explains that when Patriarch Alexander was dying, he called for Athanasius. Athanasius ran away because he was scared of being made Bishop. When the Bishops gathered to choose a new Patriarch, the entire Catholic community surrounded the church. They raised their hands to Heaven and shouted, "Give us Athanasius!" The Bishops had no one else to choose from. So, as Gregory tells us, Athanasius was elected. Pope Gregory I had full access to the Vatican Archives.

There has been a trend in writing the history of this period to depict Hellenistic art as a decadent style, following of the Golden Age of Classical Athens. Pliny the Elder, after having described the sculpture of the classical period says: Cessavit deinde ars then art disappeared. The 18th century terms Baroque and Rococo have sometimes been applied, to the art of this complex and individual period. The renewal of the historiographical approach as well as some recent discoveries, such as the tombs of Vergina, allow a better appreciation of this period's artistic richness.

Many writers have described Hellenistic art as a decline after the great art of Classical Athens. Pliny the Elder noted that after the classical period, "art disappeared." In the 18th century, the terms Baroque and Rococo were sometimes used to describe the art from this unique period. However, new research and discoveries, like the tombs of Vergina, help us better understand and appreciate the richness of art from this time.

Many writers say that Hellenistic art is not as good as the great art from Classical Athens. Pliny the Elder even said that after the classical period, "art disappeared." In the 18th century, people sometimes called this art Baroque or Rococo. However, new research and discoveries, like the tombs of Vergina, show us that the art from this time is actually rich and valuable.

The Church of England declared its independence from the Catholic Church at the time of the Elizabethan Religious Settlement. Many of the new Anglican formularies of the mid-16th century corresponded closely to those of contemporary Reformed tradition. These reforms were understood by one of those most responsible for them, the then Archbishop of Canterbury Thomas Cranmer, as navigating a middle way between two of the emerging Protestant traditions, namely Lutheranism and Calvinism. By the end of the century, the retention in Anglicanism of many traditional liturgical forms and of the episcopate was already seen as unacceptable by those promoting the most developed Protestant principles.

The Church of England became independent from the Catholic Church during the Elizabethan Religious Settlement. In the mid-16th century, many new Anglican practices were similar to those of the Reformed tradition. Thomas Cranmer, the Archbishop of Canterbury at the time, saw these changes as a way to balance between two main Protestant groups: Lutheranism and Calvinism. However, by the end of the century, many who supported stronger Protestant ideas found the Anglican Church's use of traditional worship and bishops to be unacceptable.

Concerns have often been raised over the buying public's moral complicity in purchasing products assembled or otherwise manufactured in developing countries with child labour. However, others have raised concerns that boycotting products manufactured through child labour may force these children to turn to more dangerous or strenuous professions, such as prostitution or agriculture. For example, a UNICEF study found that after the Child Labour Deterrence Act was introduced in the US, an estimated 50,000 children were dismissed from their garment industry jobs in Bangladesh, leaving many to resort to jobs such as "stone-crushing, street hustling, and prostitution," jobs that are "more hazardous and exploitative than garment production." The study suggests that boycotts are "blunt instruments with long-term consequences, that can actually harm rather than help the children involved."

Many people worry about buying products made in developing countries where child labor is used. They feel guilty about supporting this practice. However, some argue that if we stop buying these products, it might push children into even worse jobs, like prostitution or dangerous agricultural work. For instance, a UNICEF study showed that after the US passed the Child Labour Deterrence Act, around 50,000 children lost their jobs in Bangladesh's garment industry. Many of these children ended up in more dangerous jobs, like stone-crushing or street hustling. The study suggests that boycotting these products can have serious negative effects and may actually hurt the children instead of helping them.

Sila (Sanskrit) or sila (Pali) is usually translated into English as "virtuous behavior," "morality," "moral discipline," "ethics" or "precept." It is an action committed through the body, speech, or mind, and involves an intentional effort. It is one of the three practices (sila, samadhi, and panna) and the second paramita. It refers to moral purity of thought, word, and deed. The four conditions of sila are chastity, calmness, quiet, and extinguishment.

Sila, from Sanskrit and Pali, is often translated as "virtuous behavior," "morality," or "ethics." It means actions taken through our body, speech, or mind, and requires a deliberate effort. Sila is one of the three main practices, along with samadhi (concentration) and panna (wisdom), and it is the second paramita (perfection). It focuses on being morally pure in our thoughts, words, and actions. The four key aspects of sila are chastity, calmness, quietness, and letting go.

Many of the area's prominent museums are located in the historic cultural center neighborhood around Wayne State University and the College for Creative Studies. These museums include the Detroit Institute of Arts, the Detroit Historical Museum, Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History, the Detroit Science Center, as well as the main branch of the Detroit Public Library. Other cultural highlights include Motown Historical Museum, the Ford Piquette Avenue Plant museum (birthplace of the Ford Model T and the world's oldest car factory building open to the public), the Pewabic Pottery studio and school, the Tuskegee Airmen Museum, Fort Wayne, the Dossin Great Lakes Museum, the Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit (MOCAD), the Contemporary Art Institute of Detroit (CAID), and the Belle Isle Conservatory.

Relations between Nasser and King Hussein deteriorated in April when Hussein implicated Nasser in two coup attempts against him - although Nasser's involvement was never established - and dissolved al-Nabulsi's cabinet. Nasser subsequently slammed Hussein on Cairo radio as being "a tool of the imperialists." Relations with King Saud also became antagonistic as the latter began to fear that Nasser's increasing popularity in Saudi Arabia was a genuine threat to the royal family's survival. Despite opposition from the governments of Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Lebanon, Nasser maintained his prestige among their citizens and those of other Arab countries.

Nasser's relationship with King Saud also became tense. Saud worried that Nasser's growing popularity in Saudi Arabia could threaten the royal family's power. Despite the opposition from the governments of Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Lebanon, Nasser remained popular among the people in those countries and other Arab nations.

Like the rest of France, Paris has been predominantly Roman Catholic since the early Middle Ages, though religious attendance is now low. A majority of Parisians are still nominally Roman Catholic. According to 2011 statistics, there are 106 parishes and curates in the city, plus separate parishes for Spanish, Polish and Portuguese Catholics. There are an additional 10 Eastern Orthodox parishes, and bishops for the Armenian and Ukrainian Orthodox Churches. In addition there are eighty male religious orders and 140 female religious orders in the city, as well as 110 Catholic schools with 75,000 students.

The Grainger Market replaced an earlier market originally built in 1808 called the Butcher Market. The Grainger Market itself, was opened in 1835 and was Newcastle's first indoor market. At the time of its opening in 1835 it was said to be one of the largest and most beautiful markets in Europe. The opening was celebrated with a grand dinner attended by 2000 guests, and the Laing Art Gallery has a painting of this event. With the exception of the timber roof which was destroyed by a fire in 1901 and replaced by latticed-steel arches the Market is largely in its original condition. The Grainger Market architecture, like most in Grainger Town, which are either grade I or II listed, was listed grade I in 1954 by English Heritage.

Several influential people of the time, including Bell, viewed deafness as something that should be eradicated, and also believed that with resources and effort they could teach the deaf to speak and avoid the use of sign language, thus enabling their integration within the wider society from which many were often being excluded. In several schools, children were mistreated, for example by having their hands tied behind their backs so they could not communicate by signing - the only language they knew - in an attempt to force them to attempt oral communication. Owing to his efforts to suppress the teaching of sign language, Bell is often viewed negatively by those embracing Deaf culture.

Many important people at that time, like Bell, believed deafness should be eliminated. They thought that with enough resources and effort, they could teach deaf people to speak and discourage the use of sign language. They wanted to help deaf individuals fit into society, where many were often left out. In some schools, children were treated badly. For example, their hands were tied behind their backs so they couldn't use sign language, which was the only way they could communicate. This was done to force them to speak instead. Because of his attempts to limit sign language, Bell is often seen in a negative light by those who support Deaf culture.

The cartridge media of the console is officially referred to as Game Pak in most Western regions, and as Cassette (, Kasetto?) in Japan and parts of Latin America. While the SNES can address 128 Mbit,[f] only 117.75 Mbit are actually available for cartridge use. A fairly normal mapping could easily address up to 95 Mbit of ROM data (48 Mbit at FastROM speed) with 8 Mbit of battery-backed RAM. However, most available memory access controllers only support mappings of up to 32 Mbit. The largest games released (Tales of Phantasia and Star Ocean) contain 48 Mbit of ROM data, while the smallest games contain only 2 Mbit.

Processor development has reached a bottleneck due to hardware limitations. Chips are producing large amounts of heat and cooling systems have not caught up yet. A team of researchers in Switzerland have designed a chip and a cooling system that features on-chip liquid channels placed next to the hottest parts of the chip. The researchers estimate that if the technology was adopted across all chips, it could drop the energy needed for cooling down to less than a percentage of its current values. An 18-second video is available showing an animated diagram of how the water flows through the system.

Processor development is facing challenges because of hardware limits. Chips are getting very hot, and current cooling systems can't keep up. BlueNalu, a San Diego based food-tech startup, unveiled its lab-created yellowtail fish product at a small event in San Diego Bay last week. Making food in labs is already common practice and produces popular products such as Greek yogurt, Oreos, ketchup, and more. BlueNalu's fish can withstand different cooking methods, including steaming, frying, and marinating. It can even be eaten raw. The startup hopes to launch its product into a test market within two years. A team of scientists from Germany have developed tiny motors that can make sperm swim better, essentially acting as a taxi to an egg. The spermbots consist of a spiraling piece of metal that wraps around a sperm's tail. It is guided to the egg using a magnetic field. The motor slips off the sperm once it reaches its destination. No cells are harmed in the process, but researchers are unsure how the immune system would react to the micromotors. A video of the spermbots in action is available in the article.

A group of scientists from Germany has created tiny motors that help sperm swim more effectively. These motors act like taxis for the sperm, helping them reach an egg. The motors are made of a spiraling piece of metal that wraps around the sperm's tail. A magnetic field guides the sperm to the egg. Once it arrives, the motor comes off the sperm. This process does not harm any cells, but researchers are not sure how the immune system will respond to the tiny motors. You can find a video of the spermbots working in the article.

MelodyVR, a startup that films and streams gigs that can be viewed with virtual reality headsets, has purchased Napster for 70m. Napster, which started as an illegal downloading platform in the 1990s, currently has 3 million users with a library of 90 million licensed tracks. MelodyVR has hosted acts such as The Chainsmokers and Cypress Hill. It has studios in London and Los Angeles for artists to perform at. Users can pay to watch the performances through the MelodyVR app. MelodyVR funded the deal through a combination of cash and shares. Napster made 1.8m in pre-tax profits last year after delivering 10.8 billion streams to its consumers and business partners.

Tim Cook wrote a letter to investors warning investors that first quarter earnings would be much worse than expected, at around 84 billion instead of 89-93 billion as forecasted. Most of this is because of a huge drop in Chinese demand. Other divisions of Apple actually rose 19 over the past year, but the iPhone is their primary business, and sales have been sluggish especially as battery replacements caused more people to stay with their old phones instead of upgrading. Apple stock dropped 10 on the news.

Tim Cook sent a letter to investors saying that Apple’s earnings for the first quarter will be much lower than expected. They now expect around $84 billion instead of the forecasted $89-93 billion. This drop is mainly due to a big decrease in demand from China. While other parts of Apple grew by 19% over the past year, the iPhone sales have been slow. Many customers are choosing to keep their old phones instead of upgrading because they are replacing their batteries. As a result of this news, Apple’s stock fell by 10%.
